newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: C/A deficits high in some APEC economies - IMF.
newsitem.headline: C/A deficits high in some APEC economies - IMF.

text.p: The sharp fluctuations in the yen/dollar rate has affected some APEC economies by leading to a worsening of their current account deficits, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) said.
"The large change in the yen/dollar rate has accentuated the real effective exchange rate appreciation for several APEC economies that maintain relatively close links to the U.S. dollar.

"This appreciation has helped restrain demand pressures, but it has exacerbated current account deficits in some countries," the IMF said in a paper to be presented to ministers of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum at the weekend.
The paper, a copy of which was obtained by Reuters on Thursday, suggested the ministers should discuss the issue.
"Do ministers agree that current account deficits in some APEC emerging market economies are excessive ?
"In addition to considering further exchange rate flexibility, do ministers see a role for additional fiscal consolidation in addressing demand pressures?" the IMF said.
It said the real exchange rate appreciation of several APEC economies had helped reduce overheating pressures, although in some cases it had contributed to a deterioration in the current account.
The IMF said greater exchange rate facility vis-a-vis the U.S. dollar could be helpful.

With the Thai baht closely linked to the dollar, the real effective exchange rate has appreciated strongly since 1995 at a time when the current account deficit remains large, at eight percent of GDP, the IMF said.
